title: Election: Wu maintains huge lead over Kraft in mayoral preliminary as both advance to November election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu advanced to the November election after leading the preliminary with 41 percentage points over Josh Kraft.
Josh Kraft, supported by his father Robert Kraft, vows to continue his campaign despite losing by 14,000 votes.
More than 75,000 ballots were cast in the preliminary election, marking nearly an 18 percent voter turnout.

title: What to know about the viral surrogacy lawsuit
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Cindy Bi, a San Francisco venture capitalist, sued surrogate Rebecca Smith after a miscarriage at 29 weeks.
The surrogacy relationship between Bi and Smith deteriorated, leading to legal action and social media harassment.
Smith changed jobs and moved due to harassment, while Bi continues to pursue legal claims despite a judge ruling against her.

title: A healthy Hampus Lindholm could change Bruins’ fortunes in several areas
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Hampus Lindholm returns healthy to Boston Bruins after missing 65 games last season due to a fractured patella.
Lindholm, 31, aims to strengthen Bruins' defensive line and power play with his offensive skills and experience.
Bruins finished tied for fourth-worst last season; Lindholm's return could aid significant improvement this year.

title: Drake Maye receives a ringing endorsement from Bills QB Josh Allen
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bills QB Josh Allen praises Patriots' Drake Maye on the 'Like a Farmer' podcast, highlighting his talent and authenticity.
Drake Maye of the Patriots completed 30-of-46 passes for 287 yards, one touchdown, and one interception in the season opener.
Comparisons between Maye and Allen arise due to their arm strength and mobility; Maye dubbed 'mini Josh Allen' by Bill Simmons.

title: MBTA debuts train design to honor historic New England railroad, with more on the way
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: The MBTA introduced a Boston and Maine Railroad train design with maroon and yellow, starting service on the Commuter Rail.
By year-end, trains honoring New Haven Railroad and New York Central Railroad will join the Boston and Maine design.
The refurbished trains include modern upgrades like remote monitoring systems and new cameras, enhancing their performance.

title: Patriots could be facing off against their former 1st-round pick in Miami
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Miami Dolphins signed former Patriots offensive lineman Cole Strange from the Browns' practice squad.
Cole Strange, a 2022 first-round pick by Patriots, played 29 games but struggled with injuries and performance.
Dolphins need Strange as a backup after starter James Daniels' injury during a game against the Colts.

title: Tufts to go tuition-free for families making less than $150K
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Tufts University will offer tuition-free education for students from families earning under $150,000 starting next fall.
Families earning less than $60,000 will receive additional financial aid packages excluding student loans.
The policy aims to increase geographic diversity and is funded by donations designated for financial need.

title: Aunt now caring for child of parents killed in Watertown murder-suicide
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Madeline, a 1-year-old girl, will be cared for by her aunt after her parents died in a Watertown murder-suicide.
David Minasvand killed Karine Asatryan and Nadia Abrahamian in their Watertown home before committing suicide, per authorities.
A fundraiser has raised over $37,000 to support Madeline's future, covering essentials like baby supplies and education.

title: What Don Sweeney said about the Bruins’ playoff odds, timeline for new captain
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Don Sweeney expects the Bruins to be more competitive this season, emphasizing a stronger defensive identity.
Bruins will begin the season without naming a new captain, allowing leadership to develop organically during the season.
Younger players and new signings like Tanner Jeannot and Mikey Eyssimont will be key in filling roles on the Bruins roster.

title: These 5 New England restaurants make best 50 list from NYT
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Five New England restaurants made The New York Times' list of the 50 best in the U.S.
Boston's McGonagle's and La Padrona are among the recognized establishments for their Irish and Italian cuisines.
Connecticut's Haring’s and Maine's Pilgrim's Inn and Sammy’s Deluxe also featured in the prestigious list.
